DIV1.P: ACCOMMODATION, A POETICAL EPISTLE TO JOHN ASHBY, Esq
SHREWSBURY: Printed by J. EDDOWES, for the AUTHOR. MDCCLXXV.

LG.L: To view the trifler in the friend;
That friend who ever has, and will
To cheer his every anxious hour?
The whimseys of a flighty muse.
A bland, goodnatur'd, muse that must
And cowards, fools, and knaves shall be
A muse that ever will incline
To favour A---y with a line;—
That oft in person will attend him,
And counsel quaint will freely lend him:
The gambols of this frolic muse.
Sink to the brute from reasoning man!

L.HI: He serv'd his time to vile attorney;

LG.L: And vile attorneys ne'er can be
Fit subjects for a lash from thee:
What!—Give our satire for no end!
No!—Let him canter o'er the hill
Of wild Parnassus with his quill;
And stumble on without a note
From us, who think and write by rote.
The conscious muse, in native charms,
Dares every critic with a frown,—
To laud her,—up; to blast her,—down.
And gladly to that friend returns;—
Who gave her, with a gentle hand,
And feeling heart, each sweet command:—
What to embrace,—and what to fly
TO MAN AT LARGE:—without a dream
Which sways alike the clown,—the king;—
Gives strange exemplars of it's power.
The queer digressions of the muse;
And give her credit for awhile
And she can strike some lucky hits.

L.HI: Her first essay;—and all her own.

LG.L: And, if she meet with his applause,
Will lengthen out her little cause:—

L.NOTE: Analysis of the human character;—begun by the author of this little performance;—showing POPE's Essay on man unintelligible, as a finished,—philosophical, piece; but largely subscribing to the inimitable beauties of it, as a merely poetical one.

LG.L: And never idly play the fool:—
Skilful to give the finespun clew
Of GODLIKE MAN,—that GOD has made:
Midst scenes of wildest dissipation lost;—
Thro' the kindliest warmth of blood,
For every good, which it bestows
Spite of all the rage of fashion,—
He means to make a strange transition
And listen to this sage command.—
Then, then! you strike a good design.
Curse on your tame,—your frigid notions
The GOD OF NATURE gave us passions,—
To grace us with on all occasions;
And gave us reason to control
The frantic sallies of the soul.
And think him highly worth her care.
With all his faults,—and all his folly,
He's freed at length from MELANCHOLY;
And blunted praise is always lost,—
And yet it ever seems transacting.
A mere machine,—we use at will,
And keep it going on,—or still,
For keenest cuts of comic wit,—
Just when my lady's in the fit
To flourish o'er wild nature's page,
And stamp the wretch of every age.
To blast my first,—my only care;
The pillars, when they artless lay,
And by a trifling gale of wind.
So fare the laurel and the bays
Of such a rhymester's jingling lays;—
The brawling brats of coldest climes,—
The laurel claim and blooming bays,
Without the least pretence to praise:—
From us who give him,—every fear.
Stoop to my muse,—she'll teach you, how
That you the mystic muse can believe;—
They'll crawl it on,—in faith with you,
You'll have the muse's leave to fly,—
And soar it to your native sky.
First let the towering genius dare
To make high worth his constant care;—
Next let the towering genius bend
To make each honest heart,—his friend.
And never think it worth his part
To court the head without the heart:—
The union forms an higher treat:—

L.HI: But a good heart,—the deity will own,—
